Starting Tuesday, October 1, the SC Forestry Commission issued a burn ban in Anderson County. Twenty counties impacted the most by the storm, including Anderson, are not allowed to burn remaining wood or debris in unincorporated areas.

SCFC Fire Chief Darryl Jones said, "We understand people may wonder why a burning ban is necessary when more than half of the state has received so much rain. However, we’re issuing the ban not because of elevated fire danger but rather because so many of our firefighting and emergency personnel and resources are committed to hurricane-related response.” He added, "This does not include fire for food or outdoor fireplaces."

Town of Pendleton roadway cleanup

According to Pendleton, a town-wide roadway cleanup is in progress. Crews are removing debris from roads. The town reported that most debris will be cleared within the next few weeks. Residents should know that the town can only collect limbs no more than 6 feet long and 6 inches in diameter.

The town also reported that they will not pick up anything placed by contractors unless the removal is for elderly residents who need assistance and can not remove full trees. Despite the storm, sanitation services in the Town of Pendleton will run normally. Residents can continue to place their carts out as usual.

Here is a list of roadways that have passage issues or debris.

--Calhoun Street

--Cherry Street at Lebanon Road & South Elm Street

--Chester Circle

--East Main Street at Lebanon Road

--Giles Street

--Hopkins Avenue

--Jackson Street

--Keese Street

--Mechanic Street at Broad moving North

--Morse Street West Side

--Poplar Street at Woodland Circle

--Shannon Drive TCTC side

--Shirley Street

--Stephen's Road

--West Queen Street Streetscape to S Curves

--Westinghouse Road

--Westminster Street 400 block

--Woodland Circle 500 Block.

Town of Williamston debris disposal

The town of Williamston reported that on Monday, crews began removing storm debris from Hurricane Helene's impact.

Here is the Town of Williamston ordinances for debris disposal:

Tree limbs up to 4 inches in diameter should be no longer than 6 feet. Tree limbs over 4 inches in diameter should be no longer than 2 feet. No pile of yard waste shall exceed 4 feet in height and 10 feet in width. If multiple piles are needed, please ensure at least 2 feet of space between each pile.

Larger limbs will be placed in a staging area where folks will be offered the opportunity to cut them up to use as firewood. Keep larger limbs separate from smaller limbs and other yard waste. If you wish to transport your fallen limbs to the debris staging area, please contact Greg Paige at 864-958-6291 between 8 a.m. and 3 p.m. to coordinate.

The town of Williamston plans to pick up garbage on a regular schedule. This will continue as long as sanitation crews can access the landfill.

Town of West Pelzer recovery efforts

According to the town of West Pelzer, due to storm damage and the prolonged power outage, the West Pelzer Municipal Center and the O'Dell Community Center will be closed until power is restored. Staff members have limited access to email and phone calls/voicemails, but they continue to work on behalf of the Town and will respond as soon as they can access messages and contacts.

The town of West Pelzer also reported that Mayor Jim Riddle and Town Administrator Paula Payton have been in regular contact with all available area relief agencies to keep them aware of the storm's effects on West Pelzer and are receiving updates on the progress of the relief efforts for our citizens.

With these extenuating circumstances, Coffee with a Cop on October 2 and the Council Meeting on October 8 will be postponed. Residents can check the Town of West Pelzer website and Facebook page for an updated schedule.

SCDOT and Duke Energy are working to restore power and clear the roadway and sidewalks for safe use on Main Street/Highway 8. Due to safety concerns for vendors and attendees, the Fall Mile Long Yard Sale scheduled for Saturday has been canceled.

Belton-Honea Path lift boil water advisory

Following Hurricane Helene, Belton-Honea Path Water instructed residents to consume boiled tap or bottled water to protect public safety. Consumption included drinking, brushing teeth, making ice, food preparation, washing fruit and vegetables, and preparing baby formula. Customers did not need to boil water before using it for showering or bathing.

This notice was necessary because flooding negatively affected the water quality entering the water treatment plant so much that they couldn't be 100% certain of its safety. Officials have lifted the boil water advisory for the City of Belton and the Town of Honea Path.

Bottled water remains available at Leeda Poore Park for impacted families, with one case per household. Residents can resume using tap water without boiling it first, marking an step towards normalcy as the community recovers.

Town of Iva recovery efforts

According to the town of Iva, most downed trees have been cleared from the local roads. West Broad Street remains closed on the west side below Pendley Street. Only residents beyond that point should travel that portion.

Residents without power in their homes who need to charge electronic devices can visit the farmers market in Iva, which has outlets at each column. These outlets are available for phone charging during the day and night.

Cases of water are also available at the town hall for anyone without power who needs some. Garbage collection is scheduled for Monday and will be collected on Tuesday, October 1.

City of Clemson cleanup plan

According to the City of Clemson, five crews, both city and contracted, began brush cleanup in affected community areas, following a plan to expedite the cleanup as efficiently as possible. Three additional crews will be brought in tomorrow and placed in every zone.

The crews are working as quickly as possible while ensuring safety. However, they cannot safely begin cutting trees in or on power lines until Duke Energy can ground them.

The city of Clemson also reported several groups and organizations have expressed interest in helping clean up neighborhoods. If you need and are interested in receiving help, don't hesitate to get in touch with Lindsey Newton at lnewton@cityofclemson.org

According to the city of Anderson. All games/practices held at Nettles Park are canceled on Tuesday, October 1, due to power and water outages. Volleyball games are on as scheduled at Clemson Central Recreation Center. Away game updates will be communicated by team coaches

The City of Clemson reported that the recycling drop-off at the brush grinding facility on Old Central Road is closed due to the volume of brush and debris being hauled to the facility. Please take your recyclables to the Kite Hill Recycling Center until we reopen.

The City of Anderson's recovery efforts continue

According to the City of Anderson, household garbage crews will finish Monday’s routes and begin Tuesday’s routes. Curbside debris crews are focusing only on vegetative debris pick-up. City crews and teams from SCDOT, Anderson County, Rock Hill, and Horry County are tackling the remaining street closures as utility lines are removed.

The city asks that residents remember that tree limbs placed at the curb less than 12” inches in diameter must be 5’ or less, and anything greater than 12” in diameter must be less than 2’ in length. Contractors cutting trees for residents are responsible for hauling away the debris they cut.

73,000 people are still without electricity in Anderson

Since Hurricane Helene passed through the Upstate area, many residents still lack electricity, and the lack of access to essential services is causing significant disruption in their daily lives. According to the Anderson County Emergency Team, crews have restored an additional 10% of the community's power, but around 73,000 people are still without electricity.

Riley Morningstar, Blue Ridge Electric Cooperative Communications Manager, said two of the 13 substations that lost transmission service remained offline on Monday due to severe damage.

A statement from Blue Ridge Electric Cooperative on Monday reported that Duke Energy made progress overnight on the remaining transmission lines. They could energize approximately 3,500 members serviced by the Cross Roads and Tygerville substations.

Substations serving the Bountyland, Corinth, Newry, Six Mile, Dacusville, Gap Hill, Enon, Landrum, Liberty, Marietta, and Pleasant Ridge communities are now online. However, more work must be done for all members to have power. Broken poles must be replaced, and lines must be hung to get power from these substations to homes.

Senior Vice President of Engineering and Operations Mark Waters said, "we are moving in the right direction. “This will be a slow process, but having service restored back to our substations is very important.”

Blue Ridge Electric Cooperative reported that field workers have confirmed over 450 broken poles across their five-county service area, which spans 1,900 square miles.

According to Blue Ridge Electric Cooperative, on average, it takes a four-man crew about three to four hours to replace one broken pole. Replacing three poles in a 12-hour shift is a full day’s work for a single crew. Replacing four is a feat in these circumstances. These are not simple repairs.

Duke Energy's spokesman Ryan Mosier said, "We are currently assessing damage and making repairs across the Upstate. However, the extensive damage means some customers will experience a multi-day outage."

"Anderson County customers should see their service restored as late as Friday night, but we will see most customers restored well before that," Mosier said.

What to do if you are still without power?

As crews assess the situation for outages in the area, residents can receive updated estimated restoration times at duke-energy.com/outagemap . The website also has information on how Duke Energy restores power , generator safety , flooding, electrical safety, and more.

Residents are urged to stay patient and utilize local shelters, charging, and cooling stations if needed.

Anderson County offices and libraries

Anderson County Offices will open on Tuesday, October 1.

The Powdersville Treasurer’s office will remain closed at this time.

The Anderson County Library will also be open on Tuesday, October 1, from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Due to the continued power outage, all other library locations will remain closed.

Residents are welcome to charge devices, connect to Wi-Fi, and enjoy library materials at Anderson Main, Iva, Pendleton, Piedmont, and Honea Path locations.

Anderson County Schools remain closed on Tuesday and Wednesday

Schools remain closed, adding to the community's challenges during this extensive power outage. Dylan McCullough, public information officer of Anderson County District Three, stated that all Anderson County districts will observe an eLearning Day on Monday, September 30, Tuesday, October 1, and Wednesday, October 2, due to continued widespread power outages.

"Our schools will be flexible in meeting eLearning Day requirements, as we understand many families still lack access to power or the Internet," McCullough said.

The community is rallying together, with neighbors helping each other and local organizations, churches, schools, and universities providing food, water, and access to essential services. Emergency shelters have been set up for those needing assistance to provide relief for those in need until full power can be restored.

Anderson School District One will open Spearman Elementary School on Tuesday, October 1, for community members to charge their devices. The school will be open from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m.

Flat Rock Elementary and Iva Elementary will be open from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. for those who need a place to charge devices or cool off temporarily. Both locations will also serve free food from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m.

Anderson School District Four announced that Pendleton High, La France Elementary, Mount Lebanon Elementary, Pendleton Elementary, and Townville Elementary will open to the community from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. on Tuesday and Wednesday. Residents also will have access to free lunch, cases of water, ice, power, Wi-Fi, etc. Food will be available from noon to 1 p.m.

Anderson Five will provide meals for anyone 18 years of age or younger on Tuesday, October 1, and Wednesday, October 2, at the following sites: Calhoun Academy, Centerville Elementary, North Pointe Elementary, Varennes Elementary, Whitehall Elementary, and Robert Anderson Middle.

Children do not have to be Anderson Five students, but per an agreement with the USDA, meals can only be provided to those 18 years of age and younger. Children must also be present to receive the meal. Each site will operate from 11 a.m. to 12:30 p.m.

The Anderson Mall is also open and equipped with power. On October 1, residents can seek shelter and use essential services to charge their devices. Littlejohn Coliseum will open from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. to provide community members with free food, drinks, ice, showers, and charging stations.

Clemson University reported. Crews are set up for Meals, Ready-to-Eat (MRE), and water distribution near Clemson University in the P5 parking area adjacent to the National Guard Armory. Community members can drive through and receive allocations today, Tuesday, October 1, from 10:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. or until supplies last.

Anderson County Sheriff's Office Emergency Management team has partnered with Starr Fire Department to provide water for those in our community in need. The water will be in our front parking lot. Residents are allowed to take only one case per household.

Anderson University without power

According to Anderson University, most of the campus is currently without power, and there is no clear timeline for its restoration. As a result, all in-person classes, activities, and events are canceled through Wednesday, October 2.

Anderson University Student Center, including the Culinary Center, remains open for student use; all other campus operations are suspended.

Most residence halls are open but remain without electricity. Lights, hot water, and air conditioning remain unavailable until electricity is restored. The University reported that it has ample staff to care for approximately 300 students on campus.

This Saturday’s home football game will also not occur as scheduled. University officials are reviewing options for playing the game at an alternate location away from areas affected by Hurricane Helene.

Homecoming and Family Weekend activities have also been postponed. Anderson University Homecoming has been rescheduled for Saturday, November 9. However, that date is subject to change. Details are being worked out, and more information will be announced as it becomes available.

An official announcement will be made when campus electricity is fully restored.

What to do with debris or lingering trash?

Debris and lingering trash can be found throughout Anderson County. Neighbors and community members have come together to clear the affected areas.

Remien said "it really does take a community because, unfortunately, first responders can't be everywhere at the same time when that storm hits."

Suppose you need to remove debris or lingering trash from the storm. In that case, these Anderson County Convenience Centers are now open at King David, White Street, Parker Bowie, Starr Landfill, and Anderson Regional MRF. The remaining convenience centers will open as power is restored.

Residents are encouraged to utilize these facilities to help with the cleanup efforts and ensure the community returns to normalcy as quickly as possible.

Hurricane Helene damage cleanup

According to the South Carolina Emergency Management Division, if you need help with damage cleanup following Hurricane Helene, call Crisis Cleanup at 844-965-1386.

If there is property damage from Hurricane Helene, report it using the Damage Assessment tool in the SC Emergency Manager app to notify authorities. Download the app from the App Store and Google.

AnMed Health services

Since Helene passed through the area, as roads have been cleared, AnMed reported increased visits to the emergency department. If you or a loved one are experiencing an emergency, call 911.

According to Michael Burns, AnMed Health Services Public Relations Coordinator, AnMed urges residents with non-emergency medical needs to visit AnMed CareConnect locations in Anderson and Clemson. They have doubled staff there in response to circumstances, and exceptional care providers are there and ready to serve those in need.

"Hospital services are operating normally, and elective surgeries are going on as scheduled," he said. "However, our service providers continue to work to restore power and phone connections to a few of our doctors’ offices in outlying areas."

Please check AnMed.org for ongoing updates about practice closures.

Pelzer, Urgent Care

According to the Town of Pelzer, Urgent Care is open, but it doesn’t have phones. You must go in if you need service.

Medical Needs shelters in Anderson

The South Carolina Department of Public Health maintains Medical Needs Shelters in Anderson and elsewhere. These emergency shelters provide limited support for qualifying people with medical needs and adult caregivers. Call 1-855-472-3432 to inquire about eligibility for care at Medical Needs Shelters.

If a public member needs shelter and medical equipment that requires power (oxygen, refrigerated medicines, etc.), please call the Department of Public Health Careline at 1-855-472-3432 to be triaged in a Medical Needs Shelter.

Free food distribution event

Many residents faced power outages due to Hurricane Helene's impact, and families around the county lost food that went bad. If you were affected, consider attending the Second Harvest Food Bank of Metrolina this Friday, October 4, from 9 a.m. to 11 a.m. at the Anderson Jockey Lot in Belton.

Anderson food distribution is every first Friday, and Abbeville is every second Friday. The location is usually different from month to month. Every family that attends receives a 7 to 10-day food supply.

Disaster Assistance

Do you need help after the storm? https://www.disasterassistance.gov/ can help families get back on their feet following Helene. Visit the link below to see the steps you can take.

Travis Rose covers Anderson County for the Independent Mail. Reach him via email at trose@gannett.com.

search_result.title: Local fire departments find struggle in recruitment
search_result.text:
BATAVIA - There were times when the chief of this tiny hamlet’s volunteer fire department would show up to emergencies all by himself.

“It’s just one guy and one truck,” Dennis Schulz said, recalling occasions when he was the only member of his small rural department who was available to respond to midday calls.

In those cases, backup wasn’t far behind. Nearby Beechwood, which also has its own fire department, almost always teamed up with Batavia’s firefighters. In fact, the two small-town volunteer departments grew to complement one another over the years, regularly responding to emergency calls together.

Not anymore, though. Batavia's all-volunteer department ceased most operations earlier this year after a precipitous decline in membership — a problem that's reflected in the broader struggles facing volunteer fire agencies around the state and country.

Fire departments that rely on volunteers have been struggling for years to fill boots. But it's a particularly serious problem in a state like Wisconsin, where fire stations rely more heavily on volunteers than do most other parts of the country. Besides the Sheboygan area, departments in parts of Fond du Lac County have also acknowledged struggles to populate their stations.

The Batavia Fire Department, which had been in operation in rural Sheboygan County’s far southwest corner since 1908, effectively closed on June 30. Batavia, an unincorporated community in the sparsely populated Town of Scott, will continue running emergency medical services from its old fire station, but neighboring Beechwood’s department remains the town’s only contracted firefighting outfit.

"June 30 may have been our last day, but it was also our best day," said Schulz, who's been with the Batavia department since 1986 and became its chief nearly 15 years ago. Morale had been running high over the last few years, and the department had managed to replace aging equipment even as volunteer membership remained low. Efforts to recruit new members, though, hadn't turned in solid-enough results.

The town board opted not to renew its service contract with the department in Batavia, instead allowing it to expire at the end of June, board chairman Randy Narbatovics said. That's left Beechwood with a fire department but no locally based EMS service, and Batavia with a crew of about nine EMS responders but no firefighting role.

“Batavia just didn’t have the members,” Narbatovics said, noting a department roster turned in to him earlier this year showed Batavia had only a small handful of volunteers qualified to fight fires. Beechwood’s department, he said, had nearly 30.

Town leaders had previously tasked both departments with working toward a consolidation, Narbatovics added, but those efforts stalled and the merger never took place.

By his own reckoning, Schulz’s firehouse included about eight volunteer firefighters and nine members trained to handle EMS calls. With some crossover between the firefighting and medical responder ranks, the lineup stood at just 15 people, some of whom also volunteered with other nearby departments.

“Definitely, it’s not an ideal situation,” Schulz acknowledged of his hollowed-out crew, which in the early 1990s had boasted about 15 first responders and “upwards of 20 firefighters.”

Volunteer agencies face broad troubles

Struggles recruiting new members put Batavia’s fire department in good company.

The National Volunteer Fire Council says the number of volunteer firefighters in the U.S. hit its low point in 2011. Numbers have slowly climbed back up since then, but “the growth isn’t enough to meet the steady increase in call volume,” according to the nonprofit group representing national volunteer fire, EMS and rescue services.

“It’s just gotten worse and worse and worse,” Schulz said, noting he and other volunteer fire officials have been stymied by efforts recruiting younger millennials.

Nathaniel Melby, first vice president of the Wisconsin State Fire Chiefs Association, said multiple causes lie behind volunteer departments’ recruitment struggles. Melby is the chief of the Town of Campbell Fire Department near La Crosse, which also relies on volunteers, and has experienced firsthand the challenges smaller departments can face attracting and keeping members.

Sometimes, would-be volunteers are just too busy, he said. Rigorous training requirements to earn firefighting certifications can create roadblocks, too. And sometimes, poor leadership in a firehouse can turn away volunteers who might otherwise sign up, he said.

In Batavia, reasons for a volunteer shortage seemed to run a small gamut. Schulz said the tiny town along State Highway 28 doesn’t have many deeply-rooted residents, making for an increasingly shallow pool of devoted locals from which to draw new members.

“For lack of a better word, it’s just a very transient town,” he said. “People come and go all the time. There’s not a lot of people that stay there for generations.”

A lack of local industry has also added to the challenge. Those who live in Batavia, Schulz said, usually commute to work in other communities, leaving them unavailable to respond to local emergencies during the day.

That wasn’t the case just a few years ago, when a local business that specialized in making shipping pallets employed a few members of Schulz’s fire department. When the company went out of business, though, the area lost a local employer. And Schulz lost some of his volunteers.

“There’s really nothing to keep people here,” he said.

State relies heavily on volunteers

Though studies show that a decline in volunteer firefighting agencies’ memberships is a national phenomenon, Melby said the issue is even more stark in Wisconsin, where small cities and towns rely more heavily on volunteer fire departments than do most other parts of the country.

Studies by the National Fire Protection Association show there’s been a nationwide shift away from volunteer fire departments in recent years. As recently as 2001, about three-quarters of all fire departments in the U.S. relied solely on volunteers; by 2015, the figure had dropped to about 69 percent, according to studies by the group. Departments that rely entirely on staffed firefighters or a mix of full-time responders and volunteer have grown to pick up the slack, according to the NFPA.

But a 2011 report by the same organization showed an estimated 80 percent of fire departments in Wisconsin still relied entirely on volunteers.

Melby said he can’t think of instances in which volunteer shortages in Wisconsin have led to significant or deadly consequences. But the issue can lengthen emergency response times if agencies from farther away are tasked with filling the void.

“There’s a big difference between having a fire department in your community and having a fire department from two communities away respond,” he said.

Relying on volunteers to fill boots can cause headaches for departments in Sheboygan and Fond du Lac counties, where firefighters’ jobs can create obstacles to responding to daytime calls.

"A lot of our guys work outside the community," said Kyle Salter, fire chief for the Eden Fire Department, just south of Fond du Lac. He said his department boasts nearly four dozen volunteers, but fielding enough volunteers to show up for daytime calls can cause worries.

"But we have been fortunate so far,” he said, “to have employers who will allow them to leave to respond to calls. That's just part of being a volunteer fireman. We aren't standing around waiting; we have full-time jobs outside of this."

Andrew Stahl, a captain with the volunteer fire department in the Town of Sheboygan, agreed with broad reports that volunteer departments like his are hurting for members. His own agency, whose jurisdiction borders the City of Sheboygan, has somewhere between 25 and 30 volunteers, though not all are equally active. And only a few are usually available to respond to emergencies during most normal business hours.

“We have a decent amount of firefighters,” Stahl said, “but we could definitely use some more — especially during the day.”

Recruitment efforts vary

Mark Hovarth, fire chief for the Fairwater Fire Department, said the 29 volunteers on his force is a low number. But he’s counting his blessings.

"In past years we have struggled to find new recruits," he said. "But in this past year we have had five new members alone, so we are pretty lucky."

Hovarth said he’s noticed new recruits tend to be younger, an attribute difficult to come by in most of the state’s smaller communities.

Efforts over the last few years to drive up recruitment in Batavia had shown only mixed results.

Schulz, the former fire department’s chief, said his agency mailed fliers several years ago to all town residents urging them to volunteer. But the sweeping effort turned up only three new recruits — two of whom had actually previously volunteered with the department.

Narbatovics, the board chairman covering the area around Batavia, said the department’s roster as of January boasted only a few trained firefighters. He said it had begun seeing a slight uptick in recruits earlier this year even as the department prepared to close.

“But adding members doesn’t mean anything,” he said, explaining new volunteers still need to go through months of rigorous training before they’re qualified to fight fires.

‘Cautiously optimistic’ about future

A 1970s-era firefighting pickup truck still gleamed bright red inside one portion of the Batavia fire station last month, and the department had kept a few old hose nozzles as relics from its bygone heyday.

Otherwise, the department’s equipment had grown to be fairly modern. Schulz pointed to two glistening fire engines his department acquired in 2012 and 2014; together, he said, they carried a combined 3,500 gallons of water. Predicting a few years ago that membership would remain sparse, Schulz said he made sure to outfit the trucks with equipment designed for smaller crews.

The department hosted a farewell brat fry just before its closing in June, and laudatory posts thanking it for 109 years of local service started showing up on Facebook around the same time.

The department’s final days were stressful, though Schulz said he also felt a sense of relief that the difficulties of running a tiny firefighting outfit were coming to an end.

No longer a fire chief, Schulz is now the leader of Batavia’s small remaining crew of EMS personnel. He said he’d like to grow the roster to at least a dozen — a recruiting effort he knows from experience will pose a challenge.

And he said there’s a chance, however small, that volunteers might someday don firefighting gear again and run emergency calls out of Batavia’s firehouse. Achieving that, Schulz said, will require coming to an agreement with Beechwood officials to run firefighting services jointly. (Narbatovics also acknowledged the possibility, though he said it would require recruiting more firefighters to justify running the department out of two stations.)

Hammering out such a joint agreement might be hard and could take time, Schulz said. But asked if he thought it might happen, he offered a hopeful response:

“Cautiously optimistic.”

Reach McLean Bennett at 920-453-5133, mbennett2@gannett.com or @Bennett_McLean on Twitter.

Reach Jillian Ellison at jeellison@gannett.com or 920-907-7968; on Twitter: @ellison_writes.

search_result.title: Separate shootings in Millbrook leave several wounded
search_result.text:
MILLBROOK — Millbrook police are investigating two unrelated shootings this past weekend, one where multiple shots were fired at a party and the other where a woman received serious injuries.

The party shooting was reported at 11:30 p.m. Friday in the 3500 block of Boxwood Drive where there were reports of multiple shots fired, said Police Chief P.K. Johnson.

When officers arrived, they heard more shots fired from the parking lot area of a business in the 2100 block of Main Street, he said. A physical altercation at the party apparently lead to the gunfire, Johnson said. A 19-year-old man from Alabaster received a broken jaw in the melee, the chief said.

As they were investigating the shootings, police received a report of a gunshot victim being treated at Prattville Baptist Hospital, Johnson said. Officers talked to a 21-year-old man from Montgomery who had received gunshot wounds to his right leg, Johnson said.

That man would not give a statement to police and was uncooperative, Johnson said.

“Apparently, some of our young people are under the impression that it’s OK to fire indiscriminately into a crowd of people or into vehicles,” Johnson said. “We are extremely fortunate that only two people were injured, one being the result of gunfire and the other a physical assault. This type of behavior is totally unacceptable and will not be allowed to become the norm in our city.”

Since the 21-year-old shooting victim is uncooperative, officers won’t be investigating that case, he said.

“We are not getting a lot of cooperation from anyone that was present or that may be able to identify who the shooter or shooters were,” Johnson said. “We have been actively engaged in this and other areas of town where this type of activity has occurred, and we will continue to increase patrols and enforcement activity in these areas until this violence stops.”

The other shooting occurred just a few hours later, at 1:13 a.m. Saturday in the 4000 block of Grandview Road, Johnson said. Police received a report of a domestic violence situation where a person was shot.

Officers found a 51-year-old woman with gunshot wounds to her right hand and chest, Johnson said. Also injured was the woman’s 21-year-old son, being shot twice in his right arm, Johnson said. The woman is in critical condition.

The suspect has been identified by Millbrook Police as Louis Stinson Jr., a 40-year-old Montgomery resident.

Investigators with the Millbrook Police Department’s Criminal Investigative Unit have obtained warrants for Stinson’s arrest for assault 1st degree, domestic violence and robbery 1st degree.

"At this time it appears that the suspect in this case has fled the area in an attempt to avoid apprehension," Johnson said in a statement Monday. "Saturday evening our investigators received credible information that the victim’s vehicle had been abandoned just across the Georgia state line. We reached out to law enforcement officials in that area, who did in fact locate the victim’s vehicle. The vehicle was impounded and processed for physical evidence, which may be useful in assisting us in prosecuting this case. For now, our focus is on locating and apprehending the offender in this case. He’ll have to face a Judge and jury for the crimes that he’s alleged to have committed. Fleeing only makes the situation worse. The warrants that have been signed against Mr. Stinson will reach just as far as he wants to flee. We are working with our local and state law enforcement partners in the state of Georgia, as well as federal law enforcement officials attempting to have Mr. Stinson located, so that he can be returned to Millbrook and face these charges. Our investigators have been working non-stop since this case began."

Johnson asks for anyone aware of Mr. Stinson’s location to contact the Millbrook Police Department at (334) 285-6832, or the Secret Witness Line at (334) 285-8500.

"Mr. Stinson needs to turn himself into law enforcement where we can resolve this case in a manner that is safe for all parties involved," Johnson said. "Additional charges against Stinson may be forthcoming, as this case remains under investigation."

search_result.title: Sexual assaults, beatings, missing residents: A history of trouble at ...
search_result.text:
When a man was beaten with a belt and critically injured at an Anderson assisted living facility this year, the incident gave only a hint of the alarming history of trouble and violence at the home.

After 58-year-old Henry Middleton, a resident of Upstate Residential Care, was arrested in March and charged with beating Charles Larry Ross, his 73-year-old roommate who has Alzheimer's disease, the Independent Mail sought public records to determine how many times the Anderson Police Department responded to the South McDuffie Street facility in the past five years.

Ross' beating is one of at least 21 dangerous incidents that police have responded to at the home during the five-year period. Police records detail allegations of rape, residents punching each other and at least 10 instances of mentally and physically disabled people wandering away from the home and being lost for hours or even days.

It is impossible to determine which of those incidents were reported to the state Department of Health and Environmental Control, which oversees safety at the facility and others like it in South Carolina. DHEC has a record of only four serious incidents at the home, and it's unclear which incidents those are because DHEC keeps those reports for only 30 days after they have been reviewed and problems cited have been corrected.

Despite receiving multiple citations for violations, Upstate Residential Care has been fined only once, for $13,400. That came after inspectors discovered at least 33 violations at the home in a four-month period in 2014.

Discrepancies revealed by an analysis of state and city records show minimal oversight at Upstate Residential Care, and they raise concerns about the protection of assisted living facility residents throughout South Carolina.

The Independent Mail has requested records from all assisted living facilities in Anderson, Greenville, Oconee, Pickens, Abbeville, Spartanburg and Laurens counties to determine the extent of oversight at similarly classified facilities. The request is pending.

Horace Alexander, the owner of Upstate Residential Care, declined to discuss his facility or the safety of its residents for this article.

Assisted living and nursing homes are different

Contained within what appears to be a large brick house near downtown Anderson, Upstate Residential Care is licensed to have 10 residents and usually has about eight. The residents share three bedrooms on one of the house's upper floors. The same building also is home to WLAS, a radio station that plays a mix of R&B, old-school and gospel music.

At times, the person operating the radio station may also be responsible for caring for vulnerable residents, records show.

Upstate Residential Care is what state regulators call a "community residential care facility." Commonly called assisted living facilities, these businesses are cheaper — and less regulated — than nursing homes.

"A CRCF offers room and board and a degree of personal assistance," said DHEC spokesman Tommy Crosby. "A CRCF is not a nursing home, which provides intermediate or skilled nursing care."

According to state regulations, such a facility is "designed to accommodate residents’ changing needs and preferences, maximize residents’ dignity, autonomy, privacy, independence and safety, and encourage family and community involvement." Included in the definition of a CRCF is any facility other than a hospital "which offers or represents to the public that it offers a beneficial or protected environment specifically for individuals who have mental illness or disabilities."

Deborah Ross, the wife of the injured Charles Larry Ross, said the price of Upstate Residential Care was a major reason she chose it for her husband of 30 years. She said the couple's Social Security and retirement income wouldn't stretch far enough to pay for some of the places she considered.

She signed up to pay $1,461 a month, most of it going for her husband's room and board and $45 going to his medication, according to her invoices from Upstate Residential Care.

"The best place would have been $3,500 a month," she said. "We only had $2,500 a month, so it could not have been the best place. I was looking for somebody who could take care of him but still leave me money to live on... I thought for sure they would keep him safe."

Alexander said in a previous interview that residents under the care of his facility are safe.

"We are just as safe as any other residential facility licensed by the state of South Carolina," Alexander said March 2, the day that Middleton was arrested at the home and charged with assaulting Charles Larry Ross.

Alexander, who also manages the radio station, declined to speak to an Independent Mail reporter for this article.

"I'm not interested in talking," Alexander said. "You and I are in the same business. We both do media."

Sexual assaults at the facility

Anderson police have investigated at least two reports of sexual assaults at Upstate Residential Care.

One of them Alexander described as being preceded by "a staffing emergency."

In June 2014, a man who had just been released from a Georgia prison was left alone to supervise the facility's residents.

Sometime between 1:30 a.m. and 6:30 a.m., the man assaulted a young woman at the home whose mental health rendered her "unable to consent to sex," according to state records.

Donald Alexander Mitchell, then an Upstate Residential Care employee, was charged with criminal sexual conduct, according to an arrest warrant. He later pleaded guilty to a lesser charge, second-degree assault and battery, court records show.

Despite South Carolina regulations that require assisted living facilities to report all crimes against their residents to DHEC, Upstate Residential Care did not report the assault. DHEC learned of the events through a separate, filed complaint and cited Upstate Residential Care for failing to disclose what happened.

In a response to DHEC after the incident, Upstate Residential Care owner Alexander said trained employees didn't show up for work on the night of the assault. He acknowledged that the person he allowed to work that night did not have a proper background check. He said that from talking with the worker's parole officer, he was aware only of the man's "burglary-related offenses."

"There was no intent on having the staff member in question having contact with residents," Alexander wrote. "But... a staffing emergency left us between a rock and a hard place."

Alexander submitted "a plan of corrective action." DHEC reviewed the plan and accepted it.

Later that year, police responded to a report of a rape that was alleged to have occurred on a fire escape and gone unheard by the facility's staff. The woman who reported what happened was removed from the home and placed in emergency protective custody.

Serious incidents: What are the rules and what was reported?

DHEC requires community residential care facilities licensed in South Carolina to report all "serious incidents."

"Serious incidents include everything from assault and battery to sexual assault and misconduct to elopement, among others," Crosby, the DHEC spokesman, said in an email. "DHEC monitors compliance with the reporting requirements by conducting document review during inspections and when applicable, investigations."

The most recent serious incident reported by Upstate Residential Care, and the only one that DHEC still had an incident report on file for, was the Jan. 16 altercation involving Middleton and Ross, though their names are redacted from the record.

The report says that someone, whose name is redacted, admitted to beating Ross between 3 a.m. and 5 a.m. because he was "annoying... other residents, keeping them from sleeping."

DHEC provided three emails that appear connected to previous incident reports, though some items reported did not actually qualify as serious incidents as defined by state regulations.

In one July 2017 email, a person whose name is redacted notified DHEC that he was attacked by a resident whom he "took down" and restrained until police arrived. Matching Anderson Police Department records show the person who reported the assault was Alexander, and that he told police a resident had come into his office and threatened him.

In a May 2016 email, a person whose name is redacted reported having a client who was "refusing to sign admission documents" and another who was "trying everything... to return to Spartanburg County."

In the last email, from Nov. 26, 2014, Alexander gave his account of what happened when a resident wanted to leave the facility and instead stay at The Salvation Army. Alexander said he was trying to look after the resident, that he was worried about the person being able to self-medicate. Alexander said that as he tried to talk to police about what happened, the environment "turned into a hostile one" and that police were not helpful to him.

DHEC officials decided to launch their own investigation based on Alexander's email.

According to state records, a DHEC investigator listened to a 911 call in which an Upstate Residential Care resident asked dispatchers for help.

"The owner says that if I leave, I will carry an ass-whooping," the resident said. "I just want to go."

Records show that DHEC cited Upstate Residential Care for breaking state law: "A resident must be free from mental and physical abuse."

According to an Anderson police report, the man who tried to leave Upstate Residential Care was followed by a white van as he walked to The Salvation Army, and an employee of the assisted living facility told an officer that he followed the man to take away his prescribed medication.

DHEC also cited Upstate Residential Care for this, saying that the only staff on duty during this incident appeared to have left the home, leaving all other residents in the home unsupervised.

In responding to the citations, Alexander wrote to DHEC, in part: "Our facility also operates a 24-hour radio station, which is man(ned) by someone 24 hours a day who is certified in a dual capacity for both the radio station and the facility just to make sure we are never understaffed."

Further, he wrote, "at the time of investigation, we were not aware that we were not making all efforts to maintain a facility free of mental and physical abuse."

They disappeared, and state regulators didn't know

Willie Lee Shell, who was deaf and unable to speak, disappeared from Upstate Residential Care three times in two months, according to police records. It's not clear how or when he returned.

A few months later, Shell walked away from the home a fourth time.

Three days passed before someone at Upstate Residential Care called Anderson police on Aug. 25, 2014, according to a police report. The report offers little information except that he "left walking" on Aug. 22 and hadn't returned. Police sought the public's help to find Shell and told media he may have left the home to buy cigarettes.

Four days after he disappeared, Shell was found uninjured in Greenville.

Upstate Residential Care never reported any of Shell's disappearances to DHEC.

DHEC sent an inspector to the home after the South Carolina Governor's Office of the Ombudsman filed a complaint about the way the home handled Shell's fourth disappearance. DHEC cited Upstate Residential Care for failing to report the disappearance of Shell, whom DHEC called "Resident A." DHEC also cited the home for putting in Shell's records that he "rejected his medications" on five days that he was actually missing from the facility.

In his response to the citations, Alexander defended his actions.

"It appears we have become a dumping ground for people who would otherwise be homeless or public nuisances, and in return, we find ourselves the brunt of all complaints," Alexander wrote to DHEC.

What happened with Shell was not an isolated incident.

Anderson police records show that residents were reported missing from Upstate Residential Care at least 10 times in the last five years, with most of those disappearances occurring in 2014.

None of the disappearances were detailed in the four serious incidents reported to DHEC.

The state's response?

The Independent Mail has asked DHEC about multiple situations that police responded to at the home that do not show up in the state agency's log of serious incidents at the facility. Those cases include a May 2016 resident-on-resident assault and a separate incident last July involving Middleton, according to police records.

In that July case, an officer determined that a mentally ill woman had taken something of Middleton's.

"Middleton then became upset and threw a small brick" at the woman and hit her with a cane, according to the police report.

The officer did not pursue charges against Middleton because he determined that both people involved in the assault had mental health issues.

Six months later, the 58-year-old was accused of beating Ross.

Ross remains hospitalized while his wife searches for a new facility for him.

Crosby said in a recent interview that DHEC will further investigate any police cases not included in the state agency's log of serious incidents at the home "to find out if everything that should have been done was done."

Later, Crosby emailed a statement to the Independent Mail.

"DHEC has followed up with the facility to discuss the issues you have raised," he said. "DHEC’s goal is to help ensure that facilities are in compliance with our regulatory requirements for the protection of the residents that call these communities their home."

Follow Nikie Mayo on Twitter and email her at mayon@independentmail.com.

search_result.title: Cities adding and losing the most jobs
search_result.text:
Michael B. Sauter, Thomas C. Frohlich and Alexander E.M. Hess

24/7 Wall St.

Florida metro had highest job gains over one-year period%3A 7.6%25

Illinois city had biggest job losses%2C down 4.3%25

Uneven improvement in economy%2C labor market across nation

U.S. payrolls rose by more than 200,000 in November as employers continued to hire at a steady pace. Meanwhile, the unemployment rate dropped to 7.0%, the lowest it has been since late 2008. While the figures generally point to an overall improvement in the economy and labor market, the progress isn't even across the nation, and in some areas, jobs are still being shed.

In some parts of the country, however, job growth is especially strong. Such is the case in the metro area of Naples-Marco Island, Florida, where the number of jobs jumped by 7.59% over the past year. In other areas of the country the job market remains extremely weak. The number of jobs in Decatur, Illinois, fell by 4.3% over the past year. Based on the most recently available data, 24/7 Wall St. identified the metropolitan statistical areas with the greatest percent gains, and losses, in jobs.

Nationally, several industries have been driving job growth. In several of the metro areas that added the most jobs in the past 12 months, these industries have been a major factor as well. Martin Kohli, chief regional economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS), noted that "the continued boom in energy exploration appears to be a factor in why these areas in are doing relatively well." In Midland and Odessa, Texas, two of the cities adding the most jobs, mining accounted for a great deal of job growth.

In other metro areas where jobs are on the rise, the housing sector has played a major role. Job growth in construction and new housing starts have begun to pick up after reaching multi-decade lows during the recession. This is especially important for the four fast-growing job markets in Florida, Kohli explained. An improved housing market is important "because areas in Florida were among those hardest hit by the bursting of the housing bubble."

Employment in the manufacturing sector rose last year, but in many of the metro areas losing the most jobs, the long-struggling sector continued to decline. In Peoria and Decatur, Illinois, which both had among the largest job losses between October 2012 and October 2013, manufacturing employment declined 8.4% and 16.1%, respectively, during that time.

Largely because of continued budget-tightening, nationwide government employment in October was slightly lower than the same month in 2012. In several of the cities losing the most jobs, government employment declined even more. In Manhattan, Kansas, where overall jobs fell by 3.5%, the number of government jobs fell by nearly 10%.

To identify the 10 cities adding and losing the most jobs, 24/7 Wall St. examined the one-year change in total non-farm payroll from figures published by the BLS for each metro area between October 2012 and October 2013. Additional figures on unemployment and labor force size are also from the BLS, as are data referencing the industry composition of the workforce in specific metro areas. Wage data from the Bureau are as of May 2012. Many of these areas are small and data may be subject to sampling error.

These are the American cities adding (and losing) the most jobs.

1. Naples-Marco Island, Fla.

> Jobs pct. change: 7.6%

> Total non-farm jobs: 124,700

> Total workforce: 155,261

> Unemployment rate: 6.4%

As of October, no metro area matched Naples for non-farm job growth over the preceding 12 months. The metro area also added almost 5,800 workers, a 3.9% increase from the previous October. As a result, Naples' unemployment rate dropped from 8.5% in October 2012 to 6.4% in October 2013. By comparison, non-farm payrolls nationwide rose less than 2% over that time, while the U.S. unemployment rate trickled down from 7.9% to 7.3%. One major source for job growth was the leisure and hospitality industry, where the number of jobs increased by 6.7% from last year. Also, job growth in the professional and business services sector was up 10.4% during the same period.

2. Sebastian-Vero Beach, Fla.

> Jobs pct. change: 6.7%

> Total non-farm jobs: 47,700

> Total workforce: 65,024

> Unemployment rate: 8.0%

The housing crisis affected Florida more than most states, and the Sebastien-Vero Beach area's housing recovery has been slow. The unemployment rate in the area was more than 14% as of October 2009. Three years later, in October 2012, the region still had an unemployment rate of 10.3%, compared to a national rate of 7.9%. Over the next 12 months, however, things began to pick up in the area's job market. The region's labor force grew at one of the fastest rates in the country, and the economy added 3,000 jobs, a 6.7% increase. The unemployment rate fell by 2.3 percentage points to 8%, the fourth-largest decline of any metro area.

3. Crestview-Fort Walton Beach-Destin, Fla.

> Jobs pct. change: 6.0%

> Total non-farm jobs: 82,500

> Total workforce: 101,042

> Unemployment rate: 4.4%

Florida is home to the three metro areas with the highest job growth in the U.S., including the Crestview area, where the number of non-farm jobs has risen 6% between October of 2012 and October of 2013. Additionally, the unemployment rate in the area has fallen 1.3 percentage points in the most recent 12 months, and stood at just 4.4% as of October. None of this job growth has come from the public sector, as the number government jobs has been flat over the last year. Many major area employers include aerospace and defense companies, and according to the Economic Development Council of Okaloosa County, Florida, the area also offers an industrial air park for private companies to use as well as tax credits to recruit aerospace employers.

4. Midland, Texas

> Jobs pct. change: 5.2%

> Total non-farm jobs: 87,500

> Total workforce: 95,977

> Unemployment rate: 3.1%

Midland's labor force grew by nearly 4% between October 2012 and October 2013, the fifth-largest improvement out of any metro area. The region's unemployment rate of 3.1% this October was among the lowest in the nation. Like Odessa, Midland's growth may be explained in part by the booming oil and gas industry. According to the Midland Development Corporation, oil and gas companies generated nearly 3,500 jobs in the region over the last 12 months. Compared with other metro areas adding the most jobs, wages in Midland are high. In 2012, the annual median wage was nearly $35,000, in the top third of all metro areas.

5. Yuba City, Calif.

> Jobs pct. change: 4.8%

> Total non-farm jobs: 39,100

> Total workforce: 70,446

> Unemployment rate: 12.4%

Yuba City is located in the fertile Sacramento Valley and is highly reliant on agriculture. There are more than 61,000 employed people in the region, but less than 40,000 non-farm jobs. Despite non-farm job growth of nearly 5% in the last year and a 17.4% decline in the jobless population, unemployment remains a problem in Yuba City. The region's unemployment rate as of October was 12.4%, much higher than the national rate of 7.3%. Only three other metro areas had a higher unemployment rate than Yuba City.

Cities losing the most jobs

1. Decatur, Ill.

> Jobs pct. change: -4.3%

> Total non-farm jobs: 50,800

> Total workforce: 51,006

> Unemployment rate: 11.7%

Even as the Decatur area's labor force shrank, its unemployment was persistently high. There were roughly 50,800 non-farm jobs in the metro area as of October, down from 53,100 one year earlier. Much of this job loss has been in manufacturing, where employment has declined 16% year-over-year through October. Also, agricultural processing giant Archer Daniels Midland has announced plans to move its global headquarters and top executives out of the area. Currently, Illinois legislators are working on a plan to keep the company in state, offering as much as $25 million in long-term tax incentives if the company moves its headquarters to Chicago while adding 500 jobs over five years in Decatur.

2. Manhattan, Kan.

> Jobs pct. change: -3.5%

> Total non-farm jobs: 57,100

> Total workforce: 62,373

> Unemployment rate: 4.7%

Manhattan, Kansas, has struggled to grow jobs in recent years. Although the Little Apple's unemployment rate was just 4.7% in October, up slightly from October 2012, the number of jobs in the area has declined by 3.5% in the last year. The public sector, including Kansas State University and Fort Riley, home to the U.S. Army's 1st Infantry Division, is one of the area's major employers — and one of its major sources of job losses. Government jobs declined by nearly 10% in the last 12 months. Federal defense spending cuts earlier this year impacted the Fort and its workers.

3. Palm Coast, Fla.

> Jobs pct. change: -3.4%

> Total non-farm jobs: 20,000

> Total workforce: 34,424

> Unemployment rate: 9.4%

The unemployment rate in Palm Coast, fell by 1.3 percentage points between October 2012 and October 2013. Still, with a 9.4% unemployment rate, the region continues to have one of the highest jobless rates in the country. The region has had exceptionally high unemployment rates for some time, well above 10% for nearly all of the last five years. In the last year alone, the region lost roughly 700 jobs, or about 3.4%. One of the biggest factors in this decline was the estimated loss of approximately 300 the government sector jobs.

4. Ocean City, N.J.

> Jobs pct. change: -3.2%

> Total non-farm jobs: 38,800

> Total workforce: 53,525

> Unemployment rate: 11.1%

The unemployment rate in Ocean City was 11.1% in October. However, the high unemployment rate may be in part due to the seasonal nature of work in the area. There is a strong leisure and hospitality sector in Ocean City that is subject to seasonal fluctuations. This past July, for example, there were 20,200 people employed in the sector. Three months later, in October, the sector had shrunk to 9,200. Even accounting for seasonality, the Ocean City job market is quite poor. As of October, total non-farm jobs were down 3.2% over the last 12 months. Further, the area's annual median wage of $30,310 in 2012 was below the national median.

5. Panama City-Lynn Haven-Panama City Beach, Fla.

> Jobs pct. change: -3.0%

> Total non-farm jobs: 70,700

> Total workforce: 85,992

> Unemployment rate: 6.0%

Unfortunately, the Panama City metro area hasn't improved much since January, 2010 the worst month in the past six years. That month, there were just under 70,000 jobs in the region. At last count, there were 70,700 jobs. This October, the region's labor force had shrunk by more than 5% from the year before — the third largest labor force decline nationwide. Because many residents left the area or stopped looking for work, the number of people considered unemployed declined by more than 25%, the largest decline out of all metro areas. The area's annual median wage of $27,600 in 2012 remained one of the lowest in the nation.
